sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: 2 ORAL inhalations (5 mcg) once daily at the same time each day

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment: No dose adjustment necessary
  • Mild to moderate hepatic impairment: No dose adjustment necessary
  • Severe hepatic impairment: No dosing information available
  • Geriatric: No dose adjustment necessary

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Inhalation (Solution)
Salmeterol, a long-acting beta(2)-adrenergic agonists (LABA), has been shown to increase the risk of asthma-related death. This is considered a LABA class effect, and olodaterol is not indicated for asthma treatment.

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Black Box Warning:
  • -- increased risk of asthma-related death with use of long-acting beta(2)-adrenergic agonists (off-label use)
  • Cardiovascular:
  • -- clinically significant cardiovascular effects may occur (eg, increases in blood pressure or pulse rate, QT-interval prolongation, ST segment depression, T wave flattening), with greater risk among patients with coronary insufficiency, QT-interval prolongation or other cardiac arrhythmias, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, or hypertension; discontinuation may be required
  • Endocrine Metabolic Effects:
  • -- use cautiously in patients with thyrotoxicosis
  • -- may induce significant hypokalemia, which can progress to cardiac arrhythmia; increased risk among patients with hypoxia
  • -- clinically significant changes in blood glucose may occasionally occur
  • Immunologic Effects:
  • -- hypersensitivity reactions, including angioedema, have been reported; immediately discontinue if condition occurs
  • Neurologic:
  • -- use cautiously in patients with convulsive disorders
  • Respiratory Effects:
  • -- not for treatment of acute symptoms (ie, bronchospasm)
  • -- life-threatening paradoxical bronchospasm may occur; immediately discontinue if condition develops
  • Other:
  • -- loss of efficacy warrants immediate clinical evaluation, as this may be a marker of disease deterioration; do not increase dose
  • -- avoid higher or more frequent dosing than recommended due to increased risk of cardiovascular effects or death
  • -- use cautiously in patients with high sympathomimetic amine sensitivity
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- avoid use with other long-acting beta(2) agonists

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (11.3%), Upper respiratory infection (8.2%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiovascular system problem, Electrocardiogram abnormal
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypokalemia
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Respiratory:Paradoxical bronchospasm, Pneumonia (greater than 2%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Olodaterol is a long-acting beta-2 agonist (LABA) that binds to beta-2 receptors, which are found in airways and other tissues such as cardiac muscle. Beta-2 receptor stimulation triggers intracellular adenyl cyclase, which stimulates cyclic-3',5' adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) synthesis. Increased cAMP relaxes smooth muscle cells in airways causing bronchodilation.

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Hepatic: Extensive
  • Unconjugated demethylated olodaterol: Active
  • Olodaterol glucuronides: Inactive
  • Substrate of CYP2C9, CYP2C8, UGT2B7, UGT1A1, UGT1A7, and UGT1A9

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Inhalation, oral
  • prime inhaler before first use by actuating until aerosol cloud is visible, then repeat 3 more times
  • if inhaler not used for more than 3 days, actuate once before use to reprime
  • If inhaler not used for more than 21 days, repeat initial priming process
  • exhale slowly and fully, then close lips around mouthpiece; do not cover air vents
  • press dose release button while slowly and deeply inhaling through mouth; breath in for as long as possible, then hold breath for 10 seconds or as long as comfortable
  • discard inhaler 3 months after first use or when locking mechanism activates, whichever occurs first

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement or maintenance of respiratory function in patients with COPD may indicate efficacy
  • respiratory function, in patients with signs or symptoms suggestive of deterioration of disease

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that drug should not be used for COPD exacerbations or acute asthma symptoms.
  • Warn patient to report symptoms of paradoxical bronchospasm, worsening COPD, or decreased efficacy of drug.
  • Encourage patient to report cardiovascular symptoms such as elevated pulse rate or blood pressure.
  • Side effects may include bronchitis, cough, nasopharyngitis, upper respiratory tract infection, dizziness, back pain, arthralgia, or diarrhea.
  • Advise patient on proper inhalation technique.
  • Warn patient not to exceed the recommended dose.
  • Tell patient to avoid using other long-acting beta-2 agonists with drug.
